system-design-fundamentals.description: Master the fundamentals of building scalable, reliable systems

sections.title: SCALABILITY
sections.content:
‚úÖ What is Scalability?
Scalability is a system‚Äôs ability to handle increasing load without degrading performance.
In simple terms:
Can your system grow gracefully when more users or data come in?
There are two types:
* Vertical Scalability (Scaling Up): Add more power (CPU, RAM) to your existing machine.

* Horizontal Scalability (Scaling Out): Add more machines to your system.

üß≠ Why is Scalability Important?
Imagine:
   * A startup goes viral overnight ‚Üí user base jumps from 10K to 1 million.

   * If your system isn‚Äôt scalable, it crashes ‚Üí bad user experience ‚Üí lost revenue.

üîç Benefits:
      * Handles traffic spikes (Black Friday sales, IPL streaming)

      * Reduces downtime and user frustration

      * Future-proofs your architecture

      * Enables business growth

üìå When Should You Focus on Scalability?
When
	Example
	Early-stage MVP
	Not required unless you expect immediate virality
	Mid-stage product
	When you have steady user growth
	Pre-launch of major event
	e.g., Netflix before a global release
	Post-mortem
	After crashes due to unscalable systems
	Rule of thumb:
Build for simplicity first ‚Üí Scale when needed.

‚öôÔ∏è How to Achieve Scalability
1. Stateless Architecture
         * Avoid keeping data in server memory.

         * Use databases or external storage for sessions.

         * Example: REST APIs are stateless ‚Üí easier to add more servers.

2. Load Balancing
            * Distribute traffic across multiple servers.

            * Example: Amazon ELB, NGINX.

3. Horizontal Scaling
               * Add servers to handle load.

               * Used by Facebook, Uber, Instagram.

4. Database Partitioning / Sharding
                  * Split large databases into smaller chunks (shards).

                  * Example: Twitter shards user data by user ID.

5. Caching
                     * Reduce load on database by caching frequent queries.

                     * Tools: Redis, Memcached.

6. Asynchronous Processing
                        * Offload time-consuming tasks (e.g., video processing).

                        * Use message queues like Kafka or RabbitMQ.

üè≠ Real-World Example: Scalability in Action
üü° Netflix
                           * Netflix has millions of users streaming at the same time.

                           * How they scale:

                              * Horizontal scaling of servers on AWS.

                              * Microservices architecture: video encoding, user service, recommendation engine run independently.

                              * CDNs for video delivery (more in Topic 7).

                              * Chaos Monkey tests how scalable and fault-tolerant the system is under failure.

üü¢ Amazon
                                 * On Prime Day, load spikes 10x normal traffic.

                                 * Scales via:

                                    * Load balancing

                                    * Auto-scaling groups (AWS EC2)

                                    * Distributed databases

                                    * Queue-based architecture for order fulfillment

üîÑ Vertical vs Horizontal Scaling (Comparison)
Feature
	Vertical
	Horizontal
	Scaling Method
	Add resources to one machine
	Add more machines
	Cost
	Expensive hardware
	Commodity servers
	Limit
	Hardware limits
	Practically unlimited
	Downtime
	Possible
	Less likely
	Use Case
	Legacy systems
	Modern cloud apps

‚ö†Ô∏è Challenges in Scalability
                                       * Data consistency: harder when distributed

                                       * Latency: may increase with more servers

                                       * Infrastructure complexity

                                       * Cost: managing a large cluster

üí° Design Tip:
Scale bottlenecks, not everything.
 Use monitoring tools (Datadog, Prometheus, etc.) to find what‚Äôs actually slowing things down.

‚úÖ Summary
Aspect
	Key Insight
	What
	System's ability to handle more load
	Why
	To ensure performance under growth
	When
	As you scale users/data or expect spikes
	How
	Load balancers, sharding, statelessness, caching, message queues
	Real-World
	Netflix, Amazon, Uber all use these principles

sections.title: AVAILABILITY
sections.content:
‚úÖ What is Availability?
Availability is the ability of a system to remain accessible and operational when needed.
In short:
Can users interact with your system anytime they want, without failure?
It's typically measured as a percentage of uptime over total time, e.g.:
                                          * 99.9% = ~8.76 hours of downtime/year

                                          * 99.99% = ~52.6 minutes of downtime/year

üß≠ Why is Availability Important?
If your system isn't available:
                                             * üö´ Users can‚Äôt access services ‚Üí poor experience

                                             * üìâ Revenue loss (e.g., Amazon loses ~$13M per hour if down)

                                             * ‚ùå Trust is lost (especially in banking, healthcare, transport)

In many systems, availability is more critical than perfect accuracy or performance.

üìå When to Prioritize Availability
Scenario
	Example
	High-demand apps
	Instagram, WhatsApp, Uber
	Financial systems
	Stock trading platforms
	Real-time services
	Video conferencing, payments
	Global access systems
	Cloud storage (Google Drive, Dropbox)

‚öôÔ∏è How to Achieve High Availability
üîÅ 1. Redundancy
                                                * Multiple instances of services or databases.

                                                * If one fails, others take over.

                                                * Example: Two backend servers behind a load balancer.

üåç 2. Replication
                                                   * Data is copied across multiple machines or regions.

                                                   * Used in databases (e.g., MongoDB Replica Set, MySQL Master-Slave).

‚öñÔ∏è 3. Load Balancers
                                                      * Distribute traffic across healthy instances.

                                                      * Automatically skip failed ones.

üí• 4. Failover Mechanism
                                                         * Automatic switch to backup system during failure.

                                                         * Example: AWS RDS Multi-AZ failover.

üõë 5. Graceful Degradation
                                                            * If a service fails, the system still functions in a limited way.

                                                            * Example: Netflix shows cached content if recommendation engine is down.

‚è±Ô∏è 6. Health Checks and Monitoring
                                                               * Continuously ping services to detect failure early.

                                                               * Tools: Prometheus, Grafana, AWS CloudWatch.

‚òÅÔ∏è 7. Distributed Systems
                                                                  * Spread services across data centers and regions.

                                                                  * Prevents complete failure from one regional outage.

üè≠ Real-World Examples:
üü° WhatsApp
                                                                     * Relies on active-passive architecture.

                                                                     * If a data center in India fails, users are routed to backup servers in Singapore.

                                                                     * Message queues ensure messages aren't lost when a node is down.

üü¢ Amazon
                                                                        * Runs services in Availability Zones (AZs) ‚Äî isolated data centers.

                                                                        * Even if one AZ fails, services reroute traffic to another AZ.

                                                                        * Auto-restarts failed EC2 instances.

üîµ Gmail
                                                                           * Uses redundancy and geo-replication.

                                                                           * If the primary server dies, user gets access via backup replica in another region.

üîÑ High Availability vs Fault Tolerance vs Reliability
Concept
	Meaning
	High Availability
	System is always up and running
	Fault Tolerance
	System continues despite hardware/software failures
	Reliability
	System consistently performs correctly over time

üìê Designing for Nines (SLAs)
Availability
	Downtime/year
	99% (two nines)
	~3.65 days
	99.9% (three nines)
	~8.76 hours
	99.99% (four nines)
	~52.6 minutes
	99.999% (five nines)
	~5.26 minutes
	‚ö†Ô∏è The more 9s, the harder and costlier it gets.

‚ö†Ô∏è Challenges in Availability
                                                                              * More replicas = more sync overhead

                                                                              * Failover must be fast and accurate

                                                                              * Redundancy adds cost

                                                                              * Split-brain issues in replication

                                                                              * Consistency trade-offs (we'll discuss in CAP Theorem next)

üí° Design Tip
Treat every component as potentially faulty.
Design with failure in mind, not just success.

‚úÖ Summary
Aspect
	Key Insight
	What
	System‚Äôs ability to remain operational
	Why
	Ensure trust, revenue, uptime
	When
	Real-time, global, financial systems
	How
	Replication, load balancers, failover, health checks
	Real-World
	WhatsApp, Amazon, Gmail all aim for 99.99%+ uptime

sections.title: LATENCY vs THROUGHPUT
sections.content:
‚úÖ What Are Latency and Throughput?
These are performance metrics that describe how efficiently a system responds and processes workloads.
Metric
	Definition
	Analogy
	Latency
	Time taken to process a single request
	Time it takes a food delivery person to deliver one order
	Throughput
	Number of requests processed per unit time
	Number of orders a delivery company completes per hour

üß≠ Why Are They Important?
They define:
                                                                                 * User experience (Is the system slow or snappy?)

                                                                                 * System capacity (Can it handle peak load?)

                                                                                 * Scaling strategy (Should we focus on speed or volume?)

üîç Examples:
                                                                                    * Low latency ‚Üí Google Search responds in milliseconds.

                                                                                    * High throughput ‚Üí YouTube processes thousands of video uploads per minute.

üìå When Do You Optimize for What?
Scenario
	Focus
	Example
	Real-time chat
	Low Latency
	WhatsApp messages
	Batch processing
	High Throughput
	Hadoop jobs or log aggregators
	Online gaming
	Ultra-low Latency
	PUBG, Fortnite
	Video streaming backend
	High Throughput
	Netflix transcoding pipeline

‚öôÔ∏è How to Improve Latency
                                                                                       1. Use Caching

                                                                                          * Store frequently accessed data in-memory (Redis, Memcached).

                                                                                          * Example: Serve profile info from cache in Instagram.

                                                                                             2. Geographic Distribution (CDN)

                                                                                                * Bring content closer to users.

                                                                                                * Example: Cloudflare caches assets near the user.

                                                                                                   3. Efficient Code & Algorithms

                                                                                                      * Optimize queries, reduce nested loops, use indexing.

                                                                                                      * Example: Uber optimizes routing algorithms to reduce trip planning latency.

                                                                                                         4. Reduce Network Hops

                                                                                                            * Avoid unnecessary service-to-service calls.

                                                                                                            * Collapse microservices if they create latency chains.

‚öôÔ∏è How to Improve Throughput
                                                                                                               1. Horizontal Scaling

                                                                                                                  * Add more servers to increase parallel processing.

                                                                                                                  * Example: Amazon handles millions of orders by scaling backend services.

                                                                                                                     2. Asynchronous Processing

                                                                                                                        * Offload work to background workers using message queues (e.g., RabbitMQ, Kafka).

                                                                                                                        * Example: YouTube uses async workers to process uploaded videos.

                                                                                                                           3. Batch Processing

                                                                                                                              * Group and process multiple items at once.

                                                                                                                              * Example: Email campaigns send millions of emails via batch jobs.

                                                                                                                                 4. Database Optimization

                                                                                                                                    * Use write-optimized databases or partitioning for high write throughput.

                                                                                                                                    * Example: Twitter partitions tweet storage based on user ID.

üè≠ Real-World Examples
üü° Google Search
                                                                                                                                       * Focuses heavily on low latency: users expect results in under 200ms.

                                                                                                                                       * Uses global data centers, caching, and optimized ranking algorithms.

üü¢ Kafka at LinkedIn
                                                                                                                                          * Handles millions of messages per second (high throughput).

                                                                                                                                          * Used for analytics, activity logs, email notifications.

üîµ Uber
                                                                                                                                             * Trip request ‚Üí low latency expected (<100ms).

                                                                                                                                             * Logs, location tracking ‚Üí high throughput processing via streaming systems.

üß™ Latency vs Throughput: Visualized
Imagine a water pipe:
                                                                                                                                                * Latency = Time it takes for one drop of water to reach the end.

                                                                                                                                                * Throughput = Amount of water flowing per second.

You can:
                                                                                                                                                   * Reduce latency by shortening the pipe (faster network/computation).

                                                                                                                                                   * Increase throughput by widening the pipe (parallelism, batching).

‚öñÔ∏è Latency vs Throughput: Trade-offs
Trade-Off
	Description
	Batching increases throughput, but adds latency
	Email delivery system sends in bulk, but may delay individual mails
	Concurrency can boost throughput, but causes contention
	DB with too many threads may lock resources
	Compression reduces transfer time (latency), but adds CPU load
	Depends on what matters more
	You often can't fully optimize both at the same time.

üí° Design Tip
Start with low latency for user-facing services, and optimize throughput for backend pipelines.

‚úÖ Summary
Concept
	Latency
	Throughput
	Definition
	Time per request
	Requests per unit time
	Focus
	Speed
	Capacity
	Improves
	User experience
	System efficiency
	Real-World Use
	Google Search, Chat Apps
	Kafka, Analytics, Batch Jobs

sections.title: CAP THEOREM
sections.content:
‚úÖ What Is CAP Theorem?
CAP stands for:
                                                                                                                                                      * C ‚Äì Consistency: Every read receives the most recent write (no stale data).

                                                                                                                                                      * A ‚Äì Availability: Every request gets a (non-error) response, without guaranteeing it‚Äôs the latest.

                                                                                                                                                      * P ‚Äì Partition Tolerance: The system continues to function even if there‚Äôs a network partition (communication failure between nodes).

‚ö†Ô∏è Theorem:
In a distributed system, you can only guarantee two out of the three (C, A, P) at any given time.

üß≠ Why Is CAP Theorem Important?
When building distributed systems, failures are inevitable (e.g., network issues, crashed servers). You need to decide:
                                                                                                                                                         * Should you return stale data or fail the request?

                                                                                                                                                         * Should you wait for consistency or prioritize response?

CAP forces you to choose trade-offs.

üìå When Does CAP Apply?
                                                                                                                                                            * In distributed systems (any system with more than one server or node).

                                                                                                                                                            * Especially relevant for:

                                                                                                                                                               * Cloud-native apps (AWS, GCP)

                                                                                                                                                               * NoSQL databases

                                                                                                                                                               * Microservices

                                                                                                                                                               * Replicated services

‚öôÔ∏è Breakdown of the Three Components
Property
	Explanation
	Example
	Consistency
	All nodes return the same data, even after updates
	After a user updates their profile, all servers show the new name
	Availability
	System always responds (success or error), even during failure
	Even if DB is down, service returns cached data or defaults
	Partition Tolerance
	System keeps running even if network link between nodes fails
	A chat app still lets users send messages even during network glitches

üìê CAP Trade-offs: Choose Two
Type
	Guarantees
	Compromises
	CA (No Partition Tolerance)
	Strong consistency and availability
	Fails during partition (not practical for distributed systems)
	CP
	Consistency and partition tolerance
	May sacrifice availability (e.g., timeout)
	AP
	Availability and partition tolerance
	May return stale data (eventual consistency)
	üìå In real-world distributed systems, partition tolerance is non-negotiable ‚Üí so the real trade-off is between Consistency and Availability.

üè≠ Real-World Examples
üü¢ CP Systems (Consistency + Partition Tolerance)
                                                                                                                                                                  * HBase, MongoDB (with strong consistency), Redis (in single-master mode)

                                                                                                                                                                  * ‚ö†Ô∏è May reject reads/writes during partition to preserve data integrity

                                                                                                                                                                  * Example: Banking systems (can‚Äôt show stale account balance)

üü° AP Systems (Availability + Partition Tolerance)
                                                                                                                                                                     * Cassandra, Couchbase, DynamoDB

                                                                                                                                                                     * Prioritize availability ‚Üí return possibly stale data

                                                                                                                                                                     * Use eventual consistency: data will become consistent later

                                                                                                                                                                     * Example: Amazon shopping cart ‚Äì if service is down, it queues updates and syncs later

üî¥ CA Systems (No Partition Tolerance)
                                                                                                                                                                        * Theoretical or single-node systems

                                                                                                                                                                        * Example: Traditional RDBMS (MySQL running on one server)

üîÑ CAP in Action: Scenario
Let‚Äôs say:
                                                                                                                                                                           * A user updates their profile pic

                                                                                                                                                                           * At the same time, another user views the profile

Now:
                                                                                                                                                                              * If network partition occurs between servers:

                                                                                                                                                                                 * CP: Block the read until the latest update is confirmed ‚Üí slower but accurate.

                                                                                                                                                                                 * AP: Serve the old profile pic ‚Üí fast but possibly outdated.

                                                                                                                                                                                 * CA: Can‚Äôt handle this scenario in distributed setup ‚Üí fails.

‚ö†Ô∏è Challenges in CAP Design
                                                                                                                                                                                    * Picking the right combination based on business priority (speed vs accuracy)

                                                                                                                                                                                    * Managing eventual consistency logic on the client side (e.g., conflict resolution)

                                                                                                                                                                                    * Complex recovery from network partitions

üí° Design Tip
Banking, orders, inventory ‚Üí prefer CP (accuracy is critical)
 Social media likes, chat, comments ‚Üí prefer AP (speed is more critical)

‚úÖ Summary
Concept
	Meaning
	Consistency
	Every read sees latest write
	Availability
	Every request gets a response
	Partition Tolerance
	Works even if nodes can't communicate
	The Rule
	You can only have two out of three
	Real-World Use
	Cassandra (AP), MongoDB (CP), RDBMS (CA locally)

üìä Example Table
System
	Type
	Trade-Off
	Cassandra
	AP
	High throughput, eventual consistency
	MongoDB (strong consistency mode)
	CP
	Prioritizes correctness
	Redis (cluster mode)
	AP or CP depending on config

	SQL DB (single node)
	CA
	Not partition tolerant

sections.title: LOAD BALANCERS
sections.content:
‚úÖ What is a Load Balancer?
A Load Balancer is a system component that distributes incoming traffic across multiple backend servers (called nodes or instances) to ensure:
                                                                                                                                                                                       * No single server gets overloaded

                                                                                                                                                                                       * High availability and fault tolerance

                                                                                                                                                                                       * Faster response times

Think of it like:
A receptionist at a hospital who sends each patient to an available doctor.

üß≠ Why Use a Load Balancer?
                                                                                                                                                                                          * üîÅ Scalability: Add more backend servers to handle more users.

                                                                                                                                                                                          * ‚öñÔ∏è Balanced Workload: Evenly distribute user traffic to prevent overload.

                                                                                                                                                                                          * üí• Fault Tolerance: If a server fails, traffic is rerouted to healthy ones.

                                                                                                                                                                                          * üåê Improved Performance: Reduces latency by routing users to closest or fastest server.

                                                                                                                                                                                          * üîê Security Layer: Often used to terminate SSL (HTTPS) connections before forwarding to internal servers.

üìå When Should You Use One?
When
	Example
	Serving high traffic
	E-commerce site during Diwali sale
	Microservices architecture
	Routing requests to multiple APIs
	Horizontal scaling
	Adding more servers to your backend
	Global app
	Distributing traffic across regions (Geo Load Balancing)

‚öôÔ∏è How Load Balancers Work
üîÑ Basic Flow:
css
CopyEdit
[ Client ]
    ‚Üì
[ Load Balancer ]
    ‚Üì       ‚Üì       ‚Üì
[ Server 1 ] [ Server 2 ] [ Server 3 ]

üîß Load Balancing Algorithms:
Algorithm
	Description
	Use Case
	Round Robin
	Requests go to servers in circular order
	Simple, general use
	Least Connections
	Sends to server with fewest active connections
	Good for sticky or long sessions
	IP Hashing
	Same client IP goes to same server
	Needed for session affinity
	Weighted Round Robin
	Some servers get more traffic based on weight
	If servers have different capacities

üèóÔ∏è Types of Load Balancers
1. Layer 4 (Transport Level)
                                                                                                                                                                                             * Works at TCP/UDP level

                                                                                                                                                                                             * Faster, lightweight

                                                                                                                                                                                             * Example: AWS NLB (Network Load Balancer)

2. Layer 7 (Application Level)
                                                                                                                                                                                                * Works at HTTP/HTTPS level

                                                                                                                                                                                                * Can inspect headers, cookies, URLs

                                                                                                                                                                                                * Example: AWS ALB, NGINX, Traefik

3. Global Load Balancer (Geo LB)
                                                                                                                                                                                                   * Routes users to data centers close to them (region-based)

                                                                                                                                                                                                   * Example: Cloudflare, Akamai, AWS Route 53

üè≠ Real-World Examples
üü¢ Netflix
                                                                                                                                                                                                      * Uses multi-level load balancing:

                                                                                                                                                                                                         * Route 53 (DNS load balancing) ‚Üí Edge Load Balancer ‚Üí Service Load Balancer ‚Üí Microservices

                                                                                                                                                                                                            * Routes requests based on:

                                                                                                                                                                                                               * Region (geo-based)

                                                                                                                                                                                                               * Health (fails over to healthy regions)

                                                                                                                                                                                                               * Content type (videos vs recommendations)

üü° Amazon
                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Uses Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) to:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * Distribute traffic to EC2 instances

                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * Detect unhealthy instances and remove them automatically

                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * Terminate SSL before forwarding to backend

üîµ Instagram
                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * Uses NGINX as load balancer in front of:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                           * Django app servers

                                                                                                                                                                                                                           * Media services

                                                                                                                                                                                                                           * APIs

                                                                                                                                                                                                                              * Load balancer caches static assets to improve performance

üîÑ Load Balancer Failover
To prevent the load balancer itself from being a Single Point of Failure (SPOF):
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 * Use redundant load balancers (Active-Passive or Active-Active)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 * Use DNS failover to switch if one LB goes down

‚ö†Ô∏è Challenges and Considerations
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * SSL termination can be CPU-intensive

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Session persistence ("sticky sessions") can break scaling logic

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Complex rule sets in Layer 7 LB can introduce latency

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Health checks must be properly configured

üîê Bonus: Security Benefits
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Hides internal server details from users

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Can throttle malicious traffic (DDoS protection)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Offloads HTTPS encryption

‚úÖ Summary
Aspect
	Description
	What
	Distributes traffic across multiple servers
	Why
	Prevent overload, improve uptime and performance
	When
	High traffic, scaling apps, microservices
	How
	Round robin, least connections, IP hash, etc.
	Real-World
	Netflix, Amazon, Instagram all rely heavily on multi-level load balancing

üìä Comparison Table: Types of Load Balancers
Type
	Works On
	Example
	Good For
	Layer 4
	TCP/UDP
	AWS NLB
	Low latency apps
	Layer 7
	HTTP/HTTPS
	NGINX, ALB
	API gateways, web apps
	Geo Load Balancer
	DNS/Region
	Route 53, Cloudflare
	Global apps

sections.title: DATABASES (Relational vs Non-Relational)
sections.content:
‚úÖ What is a Database?
A database is an organized collection of data that you can:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * Store

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * Retrieve

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * Update

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * Delete

It‚Äôs the persistent memory of any application ‚Äî from simple user login apps to complex systems like Amazon or Netflix.

üß≠ Why Are Databases Important in System Design?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * They ensure data integrity (no lost or corrupted data).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * They allow fast queries to retrieve meaningful information.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * They help in scaling and partitioning data as user base grows.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * They're central to transaction handling in real-world apps (e.g., orders, payments, messaging).

üìå When to Use What Type of Database?
There are two main types:
Type
	Description
	When to Use
	Relational (SQL)
	Structured tables with schemas, uses SQL
	Strict data relationships, ACID transactions
	Non-Relational (NoSQL)
	Flexible schema: key-value, document, graph, etc.
	Big data, unstructured or semi-structured data, scale-out needs

‚öôÔ∏è Relational Databases (SQL)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * Examples: MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, SQL Server

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * Strengths:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   * Strong ACID compliance (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   * Structured data with relationships (foreign keys)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      * Weaknesses:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         * Hard to scale horizontally

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         * Rigid schema

üè≠ Real-world Example:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            * Banking apps (e.g., ICICI, Paytm backend) use PostgreSQL or Oracle

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               * Money transfers must be accurate and consistent

‚öôÔ∏è Non-Relational Databases (NoSQL)
Types:
Type
	Example
	Use Case
	Key-Value
	Redis, DynamoDB
	Caching, Session storage
	Document
	MongoDB, Couchbase
	Blog posts, Product catalog
	Columnar
	Cassandra, HBase
	Analytics, Logging
	Graph
	Neo4j
	Social networks, Fraud detection
	üè≠ Real-world Example:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Facebook Messages stored in HBase (columnar)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Amazon Catalog in DynamoDB (key-value, eventually consistent)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Netflix user preferences in Cassandra (high throughput, fault tolerance)

‚öñÔ∏è SQL vs NoSQL: Comparison
Feature
	SQL
	NoSQL
	Schema
	Fixed
	Flexible
	Scaling
	Vertical
	Horizontal
	Transactions
	ACID
	BASE (Eventual consistency)
	Joins
	Supported
	Limited or manual
	Maturity
	Very mature
	Evolving fast
	Ideal For
	FinTech, ERP, CRM
	IoT, media, big data apps

üìê Design Considerations for System Design Interviews
Questions You Might Face:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * "Design a system for Instagram posts. Which DB would you use?"

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * ‚Üí Use MongoDB for flexible schema, high write throughput.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           * "How would you design a payment gateway?"

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              * ‚Üí Use PostgreSQL/MySQL with strong ACID guarantees.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 * "How do you scale a DB when user base increases from 10K to 10M?"

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * ‚Üí Introduce replication, partitioning/sharding, or move from SQL to NoSQL.

üèóÔ∏è Common Concepts You Should Know
Concept
	Description
	Indexing
	Speed up query lookups (explained in Topic 10)
	Replication
	Copy data to another server for fault tolerance
	Sharding
	Splitting data across DBs to scale horizontally
	Read/Write Splitting
	Direct reads to replicas and writes to master
	Connection Pooling
	Manage simultaneous DB connections efficiently

üîÑ SQL + NoSQL Hybrid Systems (Polyglot Persistence)
Many modern systems use a combination of both:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * SQL ‚Üí for core transactional data (e.g., payments)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * NoSQL ‚Üí for flexible, high-volume data (e.g., comments, notifications)

üè≠ Example: Uber
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * MySQL for trip and user records

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * Schemaless (built on top of MySQL) for location tracking

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * Redis for caching nearby cabs

‚ö†Ô∏è Challenges in Databases
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * Schema migrations (for SQL)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * Write conflicts and consistency (for NoSQL)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * Handling distributed transactions across services

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * Data modeling and indexing strategies

üí° Design Tip
Use SQL when correctness > speed. Use NoSQL when scalability & speed > strong consistency.

‚úÖ Summary
Category
	SQL
	NoSQL
	Schema
	Structured
	Flexible
	Scaling
	Vertical
	Horizontal
	Use When
	Transactions matter
	Speed & scale matter
	Real-World
	Banking, ERP, CRM
	Social media, Logs, Analytics

üìä Example Table of Real-World Use
Company
	DB Used
	Why
	Netflix
	Cassandra, MySQL
	Preferences (fast), Billing (ACID)
	Amazon

	Fast, global scale
