sections.title: CDN (Content Delivery Network)
sections.content:
‚úÖ What is a CDN?
A Content Delivery Network is a geographically distributed network of servers that cache and deliver content (static assets like images, videos, CSS, JS, etc.) from locations close to users.
Think of it like:
Having multiple local Kirana stores across a city so customers get products faster instead of waiting for delivery from a central warehouse.

üß≠ Why Use a CDN?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * üöÄ Reduce latency ‚Üí Serve content faster from nearby servers.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * üìà Improve scalability ‚Üí Offloads static traffic from your origin servers.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * üí™ Enhance availability ‚Üí Keeps serving cached content even if origin is down.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * üîê Security benefits ‚Üí DDoS protection, HTTPS enforcement, firewall rules.

üìå When to Use a CDN
When
	Example
	High traffic static content
	Video streaming, blogs, image-heavy apps
	Global user base
	Users in different continents accessing your app
	Frontend-heavy websites
	React apps, e-commerce portals
	App performance optimization
	PageSpeed/SEO improvements

‚öôÔ∏è How Does a CDN Work?
üì¶ Basic Flow:
scss
CopyEdit
[User in India] ‚Üí CDN PoP in Mumbai ‚Üí Content Served (cached)  
                         ‚Üì
            Origin Server (only if cache miss)

üè¨ Components:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   * PoPs (Points of Presence): Edge servers around the world.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   * Edge Cache: Stores content (images, videos, JS, etc.).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   * Origin Server: Your actual server (fallback).

üì∑ What Content Should Be Cached?
Cacheable
	Not Cacheable
	Images, JS, CSS, Fonts
	Dynamic HTML (unless pre-rendered)
	Videos
	Real-time data (e.g., account balance)
	Static JSON
	Personalized content (unless tokenized)

üè≠ Real-World Examples
üü¢ Netflix
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      * Uses Open Connect (its own CDN).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      * Delivers HD/4K content from servers embedded in ISPs worldwide.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      * Most of the video content never hits the origin server.

üü° Facebook
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         * Uses Akamai and its own CDN-like infra to serve profile pictures, static pages, and ads fast.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         * Loads faster in regions like India, Africa, LATAM.

üîµ Amazon CloudFront
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            * AWS‚Äôs global CDN.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            * Used by Amazon.com, Twitch, and third-party customers.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            * Can also cache APIs (REST/GraphQL) for performance.

üîÑ CDN with Cache Hierarchy
pgsql
CopyEdit
Browser Cache ‚Üí CDN Edge Cache ‚Üí Regional Cache ‚Üí Origin Server

üß† Each level helps reduce load and speed up delivery.

üîê CDN Security Features
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               * DDoS protection: Absorbs high-volume attacks at the edge.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               * Web Application Firewall (WAF): Filters malicious traffic.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               * HTTPS enforcement: Automatically redirect HTTP to HTTPS.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               * Bot protection: Blocks scraping, fake signups, etc.

üîß Popular CDN Providers
Provider
	Notes
	Cloudflare
	Security + performance (free tier available)
	Akamai
	Industry veteran, used by enterprise clients
	AWS CloudFront
	Integrated into AWS stack
	Fastly
	Used by Reddit, GitHub, Shopify
	Google CDN
	Fast edge delivery on GCP

‚ö†Ô∏è Challenges with CDNs
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Cache invalidation (what if your file changes?)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Dynamic content needs special handling

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Sometimes adds complexity to DevOps

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Must configure HTTP headers (e.g., Cache-Control, ETag) properly

üí° Design Tip
Always use a CDN for static content and global user base.
Combine with lazy loading and minification for full performance gain.

‚úÖ Summary
Aspect
	Value
	What
	A network of edge servers caching & delivering content
	Why
	Faster load times, reduced origin load, better availability
	When
	High traffic, global apps, frontend-heavy sites
	Used By
	Netflix, Amazon, Facebook, Shopify
	Bonus
	Security, failover, bandwidth savings

üîÅ Example Use Case: Loading an E-commerce Homepage
csharp
CopyEdit
- HTML loaded from origin (cached with short TTL)
- Images, fonts, JS loaded from CDN (Cloudflare)
- Product API response fetched from origin via REST

sections.title: Message Queues
sections.content:
‚úÖ What is a Message Queue?
A Message Queue is a system component that lets different services communicate asynchronously by sending and receiving messages via a queue.
Think of it like:
A "task basket" where Service A drops a task, and Service B picks it up and works on it when ready.

üß≠ Why Use a Message Queue?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * ‚úÖ Decouples services ‚Üí Services don‚Äôt need to know about each other's availability.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * üìà Improves scalability ‚Üí Queues can buffer traffic spikes.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * üîÑ Enables retries ‚Üí Failed messages can be retried later.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * üí• Failure isolation ‚Üí One slow service doesn‚Äôt affect others.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * üß™ Asynchronous processing ‚Üí Ideal for long-running or background tasks.

üßØ When to Use a Message Queue
Use Case
	Example
	Asynchronous processing
	Email/SMS sending, thumbnail generation
	Event-driven architecture
	Order placed ‚Üí notify inventory + analytics
	Load buffering
	Sudden traffic spikes (e.g., flash sale)
	Decoupling microservices
	Billing, shipping, notification services
	Logging & analytics
	App sends logs to ELK stack via queue

‚öôÔ∏è How Does It Work?
css
CopyEdit
[Producer Service] ‚Üí [Message Queue] ‚Üí [Consumer Service]

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        1. Producer pushes messages to the queue.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        2. Queue stores them temporarily.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        3. Consumer pulls and processes them.

üèóÔ∏è Core Components
Component
	Role
	Producer
	Sends messages
	Queue
	Buffers the messages
	Consumer
	Processes messages
	Broker
	Message queue server (e.g., RabbitMQ, Kafka)
	Acknowledgment
	Confirms message was successfully processed

üè≠ Real-World Examples
üü¢ Uber
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           * Uses Kafka to handle events like ride updates, driver availability, and payment workflows.

üü° LinkedIn
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              * Built Apache Kafka to handle billions of activity events (posts, likes, messages).

üîµ Amazon
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 * Uses Amazon SQS to decouple systems like order processing, shipment tracking, email notifications.

üî¥ YouTube
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Video uploaded ‚Üí message sent to queue ‚Üí backend generates multiple resolutions asynchronously.

üß± Popular Message Queue Systems
System
	Notes
	RabbitMQ
	Easy to set up, uses AMQP protocol
	Apache Kafka
	High-throughput, distributed pub-sub system
	Amazon SQS
	Managed, scalable, AWS-native
	Google Pub/Sub
	Google Cloud's managed service
	Redis Streams
	Lightweight stream-based MQ

üß™ Delivery Models
Model
	Meaning
	At most once
	Might lose messages, no retry
	At least once
	Guaranteed delivery, may duplicate
	Exactly once
	Complex, ensures no loss or duplication
	üí° Most real systems aim for "at least once" with idempotent consumers.

üßØ Failure Handling
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * ‚úÖ Retry failed messages (e.g., 3 attempts)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * ‚úÖ Dead-letter queues (DLQ): Send failed messages for later inspection

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * ‚úÖ Message timeout: Detect stuck consumers

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * ‚úÖ Backoff strategy: Exponential retry intervals

üîê Security Concerns
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * Authentication/Authorization for producers & consumers

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * Encrypted transport (TLS)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * Message signing (optional for integrity)

üß† Design Tip
If your system needs to handle sudden bursts of data or needs loose coupling between services, use a message queue.

‚úÖ Summary
Aspect
	Value
	What
	A way to decouple communication between services
	Why
	Scalability, fault tolerance, buffering, async
	When
	Microservices, async jobs, background tasks
	Used By
	Uber, Amazon, LinkedIn, YouTube
	Common Tools
	Kafka, RabbitMQ, SQS, Pub/Sub

üñºÔ∏è Quick Visual:
css
CopyEdit
[Order Service] ‚Üí Kafka ‚Üí [Inventory Service]
                       ‚Üí Kafka ‚Üí [Email Service]

üß† Example Use Case: E-commerce Checkout
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             1. User checks out ‚Üí order_placed event sent to Kafka.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             2. Inventory service deducts stock.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             3. Email service sends confirmation.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             4. Analytics logs user behavior.

üß© None of these services are directly calling each other. They are all connected through the queue.

sections.title: Rate Limiting
sections.content:
‚úÖ What is Rate Limiting?
Rate Limiting is a technique used to restrict the number of requests a user, device, or system can make to a service within a certain time frame.
Think of it like:
‚ÄúOnly 100 requests per minute are allowed from each IP.‚Äù

üéØ Why Use Rate Limiting?
Reason
	Explanation
	‚úÖ Protect resources
	Prevents system overloads
	üîê Prevent abuse
	Avoid DDoS attacks or API misuse
	üí∞ Enforce quotas
	Control API usage for different pricing tiers
	‚öñÔ∏è Fairness
	Prevents a single user from hogging resources
	üîß Control traffic
	Smoothens sudden traffic spikes (throttling)

üßØ When to Apply Rate Limiting
Use Case
	Example
	Public APIs
	GitHub allows only 5000 requests/hour per user
	Login endpoints
	Prevent brute-force attacks
	Email/SMS triggers
	Avoid spamming users
	File uploads
	Limit large traffic uploads
	Free vs Paid plans
	10 req/min (free), 1000 req/min (pro)

‚öôÔ∏è How Does It Work?
Rate limiting is enforced using rules + counters. If the client exceeds the limit, their requests are:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * Delayed (throttled) ‚è≥

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * Rejected (429 Too Many Requests) üö´

üì¶ Common Algorithms
Algorithm
	How It Works
	Use Case
	Fixed Window
	Count requests in fixed time windows (e.g., per minute)
	Simple use cases
	Sliding Window
	Overlapping windows for smoother limiting
	APIs needing fairness
	Token Bucket
	Tokens are added over time; each request consumes a token
	Bursty traffic allowed
	Leaky Bucket
	Requests flow out at a constant rate
	Smooth request processing

üè¢ Real-World Examples
üîµ Twitter API
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   * Free users: 300 tweets/hour

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   * Paid users: Higher limits

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   * Returns 429 Too Many Requests if exceeded.

üî¥ Login Systems
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      * Gmail: "Too many attempts. Try again later."

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      * Protects against brute-force password guessing.

üü° Stripe
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         * Limits based on API keys to control abuse and prioritize premium users.

üü¢ Cloudflare / API Gateways
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            * Enforce rate limits at edge to protect origin servers.

üî® Where to Implement Rate Limiting
Layer
	Example
	API Gateway
	NGINX, Kong, AWS API Gateway
	Load Balancer
	Cloudflare, AWS ALB/WAF
	App Server
	In custom logic (e.g., Express middleware)
	Client-side
	Optional, to delay retries

üîç Headers Used
APIs often return these headers:
http
CopyEdit
X-RateLimit-Limit: 100
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 15
X-RateLimit-Reset: 1699039200

Useful for clients to adapt to limits dynamically.

üí° Design Considerations
Question
	Answer
	Should limits be per-user or per-IP?
	Depends on the context. Login? ‚Üí per-IP. API? ‚Üí per API key.
	What happens on exceed?
	Return 429 status + retry-after headers
	Do you need burst traffic?
	Use Token Bucket
	Need fairness?
	Use Sliding Window

üß™ Distributed Rate Limiting
When you have multiple app servers, the counter must be shared across instances.
üõ†Ô∏è Common solutions:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               * Use Redis as a central counter store.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               * Use distributed rate limiting tools (e.g., Envoy, Kong with Redis).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               * Rate limiting policies managed at CDN layer (e.g., Cloudflare/WAF).

üß± Example: Redis-Based Token Bucket (Pseudocode)
python
CopyEdit
tokens = redis.get(user_id)
if tokens > 0:
    redis.decr(user_id)
    proceed_request()
else:
    return 429

üõ°Ô∏è Security Tip
Rate limiting alone doesn't prevent all attacks. Combine it with:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Captcha for bots ü§ñ

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * IP bans for persistent offenders üö´

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * API keys and auth checks üîê

‚úÖ Summary
Aspect
	Value
	What
	Restrict how many requests are allowed
	Why
	Prevent abuse, ensure fairness, protect resources
	When
	API, login, uploads, pricing tiers
	Algorithms
	Fixed window, sliding window, token bucket, leaky bucket
	Used by
	Twitter, Gmail, Stripe, Cloudflare

üß† Example Use Case: Rate Limit Login API
Component
	Behavior
	User
	Tries to log in repeatedly
	Server
	Allows only 5 attempts per 10 minutes
	Exceeded
	Server returns 429 ‚Üí Retry after 600s
	Backend
	Stores attempts in Redis with expiry

sections.title: Database Indexes
sections.content:
‚úÖ What Are Indexes?
An index in a database is a data structure (usually B-Tree or Hash) that improves the speed of data retrieval operations on a table at the cost of additional writes and storage.
Think of it like:
An index in a book‚Äîhelps you find topics quickly without reading every page.

üéØ Why Use Indexes?
Benefit
	Purpose
	‚ö° Faster lookups
	Improve SELECT query performance
	üß≠ Quick sorting
	Speeds up ORDER BY, GROUP BY
	üîç Efficient searching
	Handles queries with WHERE, LIKE, IN
	üßÆ Optimized joins
	Makes JOINs faster by indexing foreign keys
	üö¶ Query optimization
	Helps the DB query planner choose better execution paths

üîç When Should You Use Indexes?
Use indexes when:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * Columns are frequently queried in WHERE, JOIN, or ORDER BY

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * Queries on large tables become slow

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * You want to enforce uniqueness (UNIQUE INDEX)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * You are building a search or filter-heavy system

üè¢ Real-World Industry Examples
üü¢ E-commerce Search (Amazon, Flipkart)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * Products table: index on product_name, category, price for search and filters

üîµ Banking Apps (TCS BaNCS, PayTM)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           * Transactions table: index on user_id, timestamp for quick access to recent transactions

üî¥ Social Media (Facebook, Twitter)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              * Posts table: index on user_id, created_at to show news feed quickly

üü° Ride Sharing (Uber, Ola)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 * Index on location, status in driver or trip table to find nearest available drivers fast

üõ†Ô∏è Types of Indexes
Type
	Purpose
	Example Use
	üîπ Single-column
	Index on one column
	CREATE INDEX idx_email ON users(email);
	üî∏ Composite (multi-column)
	Index on multiple columns
	CREATE INDEX idx_user_date ON orders(user_id, order_date);
	üîπ Unique
	Prevents duplicate entries
	UNIQUE INDEX on email
	üî∏ Full-text
	For searching natural language text
	Blog posts, comments
	üîπ Partial/Filtered
	Only index rows matching condition
	Index where status = 'active'
	üî∏ Covering Index
	Includes all columns used in query
	Avoids extra lookups

üí£ What Happens Without Indexes?
Without indexes, databases perform full table scans, which means:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Every row is checked even if you're querying one.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Extremely slow on large datasets.

üí• Example:
sql
CopyEdit
SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = 'john@example.com';

No index on email ‚Üí entire users table is scanned row by row.

‚öñÔ∏è Trade-offs of Indexing
Pros
	Cons
	üöÄ Faster reads
	üê¢ Slower writes (insert/update/delete)
	üîç Better search
	üíæ Extra storage
	üìä Improved query plans
	‚ùå Can degrade performance if misused

‚öôÔ∏è How Indexing Works Under the Hood
üß± Common Data Structures:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * B-Tree (most common): Balanced tree for range queries, fast lookup

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Hash Index: Fast exact match (not good for range)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * GIN/GIN (PostgreSQL): For full-text or JSON search

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Inverted Index: Used in search engines like Elasticsearch

üß¨ Index Lifecycle:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1. Create index

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          2. Store index tree alongside table data

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          3. On query, DB checks index first

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          4. Uses row pointer to fetch data efficiently

üß™ Example: Creating and Using Index
sql
CopyEdit
-- Users table
CREATE TABLE users (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    email VARCHAR(255),
    full_name TEXT
);

-- Create index on email
CREATE INDEX idx_users_email ON users(email);

-- Query benefits from index
SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = 'john@example.com';

üß± Composite Index Best Practices
sql
CopyEdit
CREATE INDEX idx_user_city_state ON addresses(user_id, city, state);

‚úÖ Best when your queries look like:
sql
CopyEdit
SELECT * FROM addresses WHERE user_id = 5 AND city = 'Mumbai';

‚ö†Ô∏è Order matters: index on (A, B) works for queries on A or A+B ‚Äî but not just B!

üîç How to Analyze Indexes
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * PostgreSQL: EXPLAIN ANALYZE

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * MySQL: EXPLAIN SELECT ...

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * Use tools like pg_stat_user_indexes or SHOW INDEXES to monitor usage

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * Drop unused indexes‚Äîthey cost memory!

üß† System Design Use Cases
Use Case
	Indexed Column
	User login
	email, username
	Show latest posts
	created_at DESC
	Product filtering
	category, price
	Messaging app
	sender_id, receiver_id, timestamp

‚úÖ Summary
Topic
	Takeaway
	What
	Data structure that speeds up queries
	Why
	Avoids full scans, improves response time
	When
	High-read queries, filtering, searching
	Types
	Single, composite, unique, full-text
	Caution
	Don't over-index‚Äîaffects writes and storage
	Real Use
	Amazon, Uber, Twitter, banking systems

sections.title: Caching
sections.content:
‚úÖ What Is Caching?
Caching is the process of storing copies of frequently accessed data in temporary storage (cache) so that future requests can be served faster, without hitting the main data store (like a database or API).
Think of it like:
Keeping your frequently used items (like keys or wallet) near the door, instead of deep in a drawer.

üéØ Why Use Caching?
Benefit
	Description
	‚ö° Ultra-fast responses
	RAM or in-memory stores are much faster than disk or DB
	üß≠ Offload backend
	Reduces load on DB or services
	üìâ Lower latency
	Quick retrieval improves UX
	üí∞ Cost-efficient
	Fewer DB or external API calls = reduced infra bills
	‚è±Ô∏è Better scalability
	Handles large traffic spikes smoothly

üîç When Should You Use Caching?
Use caching when:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * Data doesn't change frequently

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * You have read-heavy workloads

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * You need instantaneous performance (e.g., under 100ms)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * Systems face repeated requests for the same data

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * Reducing cost of external APIs (e.g., weather API)

üè¢ Real-World Examples
üü¢ E-commerce Website (Flipkart, Amazon)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   * Cache product details, pricing, homepage banners

üîµ Food Delivery (Swiggy, Zomato)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      * Cache restaurant menus, delivery fees

üî¥ Social Media (Instagram, Twitter)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         * Cache user profiles, timelines, trending hashtags

üü° Streaming Platforms (Netflix, YouTube)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            * Cache thumbnails, metadata, watch history

‚öôÔ∏è SaaS Dashboards (e.g., Stripe, Grafana)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               * Cache metrics, pre-aggregated analytics

‚öôÔ∏è Types of Caches
Type
	Description
	Example
	üîπ In-memory cache
	Lives in RAM, fastest
	Redis, Memcached
	üî∏ Browser cache
	Stores static assets locally
	JS, CSS, images
	üîπ CDN cache
	Edge servers cache assets
	Cloudflare, Akamai
	üî∏ Database cache
	Query result cache

	üü® Varnish

üõ†Ô∏è Cache Design Patterns
1. Read-through cache
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * App reads from cache.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * If not found, reads from DB, stores in cache.

2. Write-through cache
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * Write goes to both cache and DB.

3. Cache-aside (lazy loading) ‚úÖ Most common
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * App directly manages the cache.

CopyEdit
function getUser(id) {
  const cached = cache.get(id);
  if (cached) return cached;

  const user = db.fetchUser(id);
  cache.set(id, user);
  return user;
}

4. Write-back / Write-behind
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           * Writes go to cache first, then flushed to DB asynchronously.

‚è≥ Cache Expiration & Invalidation
Method

	üßΩ Manual Invalidation
	Invalidate when data changes
	üîÅ LRU (Least Recently Used)
	Evict least used keys
	üì¶ Versioned Keys
	Use version IDs in keys to force fresh fetch

üí• Common Pitfalls in Caching
Mistake
	Impact
	‚ùå Stale data
	Cache not refreshed after DB update
	üåÄ Cache stampede
	Too many misses trigger DB flood
	üß® Inconsistent reads
	Cache and DB mismatch
	üìâ Over-caching
	Wasted memory, unnecessary complexity
	‚úÖ Solutions:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              * Use locking or request coalescing to prevent stampedes

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              * Implement TTL + fallback to DB

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              * Invalidate intelligently on updates

üìä Example: Redis Caching for User Profile

CopyEdit
// Pseudocode (Node.js)
async function getUserProfile(userId) {
  let profile = await redis.get(`user:${userId}`);
  if (profile) return JSON.parse(profile);

  profile = await db.queryUser(userId);
  await redis.set(`user:${userId}`, JSON.stringify(profile), 'EX', 3600); // 1 hour TTL
  return profile;
}

sections.title: Consistent Hashing
sections.content:
‚úÖ What Is Consistent Hashing?
Consistent Hashing is a technique to evenly distribute data across multiple nodes (servers or databases) in a way that minimizes re-distribution when nodes are added or removed.
In traditional hashing, when a new server is added, many keys need to be rehashed and moved. With consistent hashing, only a small subset of keys are affected.

üéØ Why Use It?
Problem
	Consistent Hashing Solution
	Adding/removing nodes breaks key distribution
	Minimizes the number of keys to move
	Load imbalance
	Helps distribute keys uniformly
	Cache or DB sharding with scaling
	Nodes can be dynamically added/removed

üè¢ Real-World Use Cases
Company
	Usage
	Amazon DynamoDB
	Underlying partitioning of key-value store
	Cassandra
	Distributes data across nodes
	Redis Cluster
	Partitions keys across multiple instances
	CDNs (Cloudflare, Akamai)
	Content storage across edge locations
	Load Balancers
	Route users consistently to the same server

üé° How It Works:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 1. Hash each server and place them on a circular hash ring.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 2. Hash each data key and place on the ring.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 3. A key is assigned to the next server clockwise on the ring.

üìç Visual Example:
markdown
CopyEdit
Hash Ring (0 - 360¬∞)

     ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ0‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
     |                         |
  270¬∞                       90¬∞
     |                         |
     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ180‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò

Servers:
- Server A at 60¬∞
- Server B at 180¬∞
- Server C at 300¬∞

Keys:
- Key1 ‚Üí 100¬∞ ‚Üí Server B
- Key2 ‚Üí 200¬∞ ‚Üí Server C
- Key3 ‚Üí 40¬∞  ‚Üí Server A

If Server B is removed, only keys between A and B are reassigned. The rest stay untouched.

üí° Real-Life Analogy
Think of a clockwise locker system:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Keys are placed at time points (1 PM, 3 PM, etc.)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Lockers are installed at various times (e.g., 2 PM, 6 PM)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Each key goes into the next locker clockwise.

üß™ Traditional Hashing vs. Consistent Hashing
Feature
	Traditional Hashing
	Consistent Hashing
	Node Added
	Rehash all keys
	Rehash only some keys
	Flexibility
	Poor
	High
	Scalability
	Limited
	Excellent
	Load Distribution
	Can be skewed
	Even with virtual nodes

üß© Key Concepts
1. Hash Function
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Use a uniform hash function like SHA-1, MD5, etc.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Ensures keys and nodes are evenly spread across the ring.

2. Virtual Nodes
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * Each server is mapped to multiple points on the ring.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * Smooths out uneven key distributions.

text
CopyEdit
Server A ‚Üí A1, A2, A3 (multiple positions)

3. Replication
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * Store a key on its primary node and N-1 successors for fault tolerance.

‚öôÔ∏è Code Logic (Simplified)
python
CopyEdit
def hash_fn(value):
    return int(hashlib.sha1(value.encode()).hexdigest(), 16) % 360

servers = [60, 180, 300]  # degrees on the circle

def get_server_for_key(key):
    h = hash_fn(key)
    for s in sorted(servers):
        if h < s:
            return s
    return servers[0]  # wrap around

üö® Challenges & Mitigations
Problem
	Fix
	Uneven load
	Use virtual nodes
	Data consistency
	Add replication
	Ring maintenance
	Automate via service registry (e.g., ZooKeeper)
	Hash collisions
	Use better hash functions

üìä System Design Application
Scenario
	Use Case
	Distributed Cache (Redis)
	Consistent hashing to partition keys
	Large DB (Cassandra, DynamoDB)
	Hash partitions for even load
	Load Balancer Routing
	Route users to same backend instance (sticky sessions)
	CDN Edge Servers
	Consistently map URLs to edge nodes

üìå Summary
Aspect
	Value
	What
	Distribute data/requests evenly across dynamic nodes
	Why
	Prevent data reshuffling on scaling events
	Where
	Caching, database sharding, load balancing, CDNs
	Tools
	Redis Cluster, Cassandra, Akamai, Consul
	Key Terms
	Hash ring, virtual nodes, replication

üìö Fun Fact
The original Amazon Dynamo paper (2007) introduced consistent hashing and inspired modern distributed NoSQL systems like Cassandra, Riak, and even parts of Netflix architecture.

sections.title: Database Sharding
sections.content:
‚úÖ What Is Database Sharding?
Sharding is the process of splitting a large database into smaller, faster, more manageable parts called ‚Äúshards.‚Äù Each shard is a separate database that holds a portion of the overall data.
Think of it like splitting a big book into chapters stored in different drawers. Each drawer (shard) stores only a part of the book (database), but together they make up the full content.

üß© Why Use Sharding?
Problem
	Sharding Solution
	Growing dataset causes performance issues
	Distributes load across machines
	One server can't handle all read/write ops
	Scales horizontally across multiple DBs
	Risk of single point of failure
	Each shard can be replicated independently
	Hotspots in data access (e.g., popular users)
	Shards distribute this uneven load

üè¢ Real-World Examples
Company
	Usage
	Facebook
	Shards user data by user ID range
	Twitter
	Shards tweets and timelines by user ID
	YouTube
	Video metadata sharded by video ID prefix
	Alibaba
	Massive MySQL sharding for their marketplace
	MongoDB
	Built-in support for horizontal sharding

üîß How It Works
There are 3 common sharding strategies:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Range-Based Sharding
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * Divide data by ranges (e.g., user IDs 1-1000, 1001-2000)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * Simple, but can lead to hotspots

text
CopyEdit
Shard 1: User IDs 1‚Äì10,000  
Shard 2: User IDs 10,001‚Äì20,000  

2Ô∏è‚É£ Hash-Based Sharding
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   * Hash a key (e.g., user_id) to decide the shard

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   * More balanced, but hard to do range queries

python
CopyEdit
shard = hash(user_id) % N

3Ô∏è‚É£ Geo/Feature-Based Sharding
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      * Shard by region or feature

text
CopyEdit
Shard A: North America  
Shard B: Europe  
Shard C: Asia  

Used when:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         * Data locality matters

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         * Legal regulations require geographic data separation

üìç Example: Twitter Sharding
Imagine Twitter stores tweets. Each tweet has:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            * tweet_id

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            * user_id

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            * timestamp

They may shard based on user_id hash, like:
python
CopyEdit
shard = hash(user_id) % 100

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               * User 123 ‚Üí Shard 3

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               * User 456 ‚Üí Shard 56

Each shard is an independent DB that handles reads/writes for a subset of users.

üß™ Sharding vs Partitioning
Term
	Meaning
	Sharding
	Horizontal partitioning across different servers or clusters
	Partitioning
	General term (can be vertical or horizontal) within same DB instance

üß† Challenges of Sharding
Challenge
	Description
	Mitigation
	üîÅ Cross-shard joins
	Can‚Äôt run normal SQL joins
	Denormalize data or use application-layer joins
	üß© Rebalancing shards
	When data is uneven
	Use consistent hashing, auto-balancing
	‚ùå Single point of failure
	If shard fails, data is unavailable
	Use replication per shard
	üìä Complex queries
	Aggregates across shards
	Query each shard, then merge results
	üöß Operational complexity
	Backups, migrations, and restores
	Use orchestration tools (e.g., Vitess, ProxySQL)

‚öôÔ∏è Best Practices
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Pick shard key carefully: must be high-cardinality, uniform

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Monitor hot shards and re-shard as needed

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Use middleware or routers to abstract shard logic

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  * Consider Shard Manager Service or tools like:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * Vitess (used by YouTube)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * ProxySQL (for MySQL sharding)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * Citus (PostgreSQL extension for sharding)

üì¶ How Systems Handle It
Tool
	Feature
	MongoDB
	Automatic sharding with range/hash
	Cassandra
	Partitions data using consistent hashing
	Vitess
	Scales MySQL with automatic sharding
	Elasticsearch
	Shards by default for search indexes
	CitusDB
	PostgreSQL sharding and parallelization

üìä Summary
Aspect
	Value
	What
	Dividing large databases into smaller, manageable pieces
	Why
	To scale write-heavy and data-heavy applications
	Types
	Range-based, hash-based, geo-based
	Use Cases
	Social media, e-commerce, streaming platforms
	Tools
	Vitess, MongoDB, Citus, Cassandra

üéØ Real Scenario
Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôre designing a video hosting platform:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * Users upload and view videos.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * Each user generates lots of metadata (views, likes, comments).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * You shard your PostgreSQL DB by user_id hash:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           * This allows the system to scale as user base grows.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           * Each DB only holds a small set of user-related records.

If a user becomes super popular, you can migrate their data to a dedicated shard, or scale that shard independently.

sections.title: Consensus Algorithms
sections.content:
‚úÖ What Is a Consensus Algorithm?
A consensus algorithm allows a distributed system (multiple servers or nodes) to agree on a single value or state ‚Äî even if some nodes crash, go offline, or send conflicting information.
Think of it like a group of friends trying to agree on a movie. Even if someone leaves mid-discussion or changes their mind, the group must come to one final decision.

üîë Why Is It Needed?
In a single server, there's one source of truth. In a distributed system (e.g., microservices, databases across data centers), we need multiple nodes to agree on shared decisions, such as:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              * What‚Äôs the current state of a record?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              * Who is the leader (primary) node?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              * Which transaction should be committed?
